data.title: Subject: Academe Today: A state flush with money weighs higher-ed cuts - The Chronicle of Higher Education
data.snippet:
Virtual Forum

The Future of Accreditation

UPCOMING: February 17, 2 p.m. ET | The Trump administration is overhauling accreditation to focus on work-force outcomes, eliminate the use of demographic data, and expedite approval of new accrediting agencies. Get expert advice on how to navigate the politics of the moment and the future of accreditation in this virtual forum. With Support From Watermark. Register now.

## The Great Read

From Our Archive

The Case for a New Kind of Core

By Nicholas Lemann

A methods-based curriculum could empower students in college and for life.

Image 1: image

Chad Crowe

_Hanover, N.H._

Families across the U.S. are questioning whether a four-year degree is worth it. Student debt has soared. Recent graduates are struggling in a rapidly changing job market. Colleges can also be too ideological: On many campuses, students are exposed to a limited range of perspectives, signaling to them what rather than how to think. About the Author

Len Gutkin

Len Gutkin is editor of The Chronicle Review and the author of Dandyism: Forming Fiction From Modernism to the Present (University of Virginia Press). Follow him at @GutkinLen.

## More News

Can AI Improve Intro Courses? A New Courseware Project Hopes So.

Data

Two States Are Pausing H-1B Hiring at Public Universities. Here’s What That Could Mean.

A Contentious Point

Why a State’s Private Colleges Are Feuding With Its Community Colleges

## From The Review [...] The Review | Opinion

By Len Gutkin

January 30, 2026

Recently on X, a professor found herself the victim of the sort of pile-on social media is so good at provoking. John D. Sailer, director of higher-education policy at the Manhattan Institute, a conservative think tank, posted a screenshot of the acknowledgments page of the professor’s book, with the following passage highlighted: “Like many people publishing in academia, I needed to write this book to theoretically keep my job. Although if we’re being honest, this is hardly enough to ‘keep’ a job in a fascist-zionist, racist, transphobic, ableist career path in a glorified settler-colonial real estate hedge fund known as a university.”
